metadata.subject: biology
metadata.dotPoint: The structure of genes: exons, introns and promoter and operator regions; The genetic code as a universal triplet code that is degenerate and the steps in gene expression, including transcription, RNA processing in eukaryotic cells and translation by ribosomes; The role of rough endoplasmic reticulum, Golgi apparatus and associated vesicles in the export of proteins from a cell via the protein secretory pathway

concepts.name: gene structure
concepts.formula: Genes contain a promoter (RNA polymerase binding), coding sequence (exons and introns in eukaryotes), and terminator
concepts.correct: Correct! A gene has three main parts: the promoter where RNA polymerase binds, the coding sequence (with exons and introns in eukaryotes), and the terminator that ends transcription.

wrong.error: You confused the promoter with the operator. Promoters initiate transcription; operators regulate it (prokaryotes).
wrong.fix: Promoter = where RNA polymerase binds to START transcription. Operator = where repressors bind to BLOCK transcription (in prokaryotes).
wrong.action: Remember: promoter PROMotes transcription (starting point). Operator OPERates the on/off switch.

wrong.error: You thought the terminator stops translation. It stops transcription; stop codons end translation.
wrong.fix: Terminator = ends transcription (RNA polymerase detaches). Stop codon = ends translation (ribosome releases polypeptide).
wrong.action: Terminator is a DNA sequence. Stop codon is an mRNA sequence. Different processes, different terminators.

wrong.error: You confused the coding sequence with the gene. The coding sequence is part of the gene, not the whole thing.
wrong.fix: A gene includes: promoter + coding sequence + terminator. The coding sequence is the part actually transcribed into RNA.
wrong.action: Think of a gene like a recipe: promoter = 'start here', coding sequence = ingredients list, terminator = 'end recipe'.

persistent.gap: You're not distinguishing the different functional regions within a gene.
persistent.action: Draw a gene showing: promoter (before), exons and introns (middle), terminator (after). Label each region's function.

concepts.name: exons and introns
concepts.formula: Exons are expressed coding sequences; introns are intervening non-coding sequences removed during splicing
concepts.correct: Correct! Exons are the coding sequences that remain in mature mRNA and are expressed (EXpressed = EXons). Introns are intervening sequences that are removed by splicing.

wrong.error: You reversed exons and introns. Exons stay in (expressed); introns are removed (intervening).
wrong.fix: EXons = EXpressed (stay in mRNA). INtrons = INtervening (removed from mRNA).
wrong.action: Memory trick: EX-ons EXIT to the cytoplasm. IN-trons stay IN the nucleus (removed and degraded).

wrong.error: You thought prokaryotes have introns. Prokaryotic genes typically lack introns; their genes are continuous.
wrong.fix: Introns are primarily a eukaryotic feature. Prokaryotic genes are usually continuous coding sequences without introns.
wrong.action: Eukaryotes = exons + introns (need splicing). Prokaryotes = continuous genes (no splicing needed).

wrong.error: You confused introns with non-coding DNA. Introns are within genes; much non-coding DNA is between genes.
wrong.fix: Introns are specific non-coding sequences WITHIN genes. Other non-coding DNA exists BETWEEN genes (intergenic regions).
wrong.action: Introns = non-coding parts inside genes. Intergenic = non-coding regions between genes. Different locations.

persistent.gap: You're confusing exons (expressed sequences) with introns (removed sequences).
persistent.action: Draw pre-mRNA with alternating exons and introns, then show splicing removing introns to make mature mRNA.

concepts.name: transcription process
concepts.formula: RNA polymerase binds the promoter, unwinds DNA, synthesises RNA 5' to 3' using the template strand, and detaches at the terminator
concepts.correct: Correct! Transcription involves RNA polymerase binding to the promoter, unwinding DNA, reading the template strand 3' to 5' while building RNA 5' to 3', then releasing at the terminator.

wrong.error: You confused the template strand with the coding strand. The template is read; the coding strand matches the mRNA sequence.
wrong.fix: Template strand = read by RNA polymerase (complementary to mRNA). Coding strand = same sequence as mRNA (except T→U).
wrong.action: Template strand is the 'mold'—RNA is built complementary to it. Coding strand just 'codes' the same info.

wrong.error: You thought RNA polymerase synthesises 3' to 5'. All nucleic acid synthesis proceeds 5' to 3'.
wrong.fix: RNA polymerase adds nucleotides to the 3' end, so synthesis is 5' to 3'. It reads the template 3' to 5'.
wrong.action: Universal rule: nucleic acids are ALWAYS synthesised 5' to 3'. The template is read in the opposite direction.

wrong.error: You confused RNA polymerase with DNA polymerase. RNA polymerase makes RNA; DNA polymerase makes DNA.
wrong.fix: RNA polymerase = transcription (DNA → RNA). DNA polymerase = replication (DNA → DNA).
wrong.action: The enzyme name tells you what it makes: RNA polymerase → RNA. DNA polymerase → DNA.

persistent.gap: You're not understanding the direction and mechanics of transcription.
persistent.action: Draw transcription: show template strand (3'→5'), RNA polymerase, and new RNA (5'→3'). Label directions clearly.

concepts.name: RNA processing
concepts.formula: Eukaryotic pre-mRNA is processed by 5' capping, 3' polyadenylation, and splicing to remove introns
concepts.correct: Correct! Before leaving the nucleus, eukaryotic pre-mRNA is modified: a 5' cap is added (protection), a poly-A tail at the 3' end (stability), and introns are spliced out.

wrong.error: You thought prokaryotes process mRNA the same way. Prokaryotic mRNA is not processed; it's translated directly.
wrong.fix: Eukaryotes: transcription → processing → export → translation. Prokaryotes: transcription and translation occur simultaneously.
wrong.action: Eukaryotes have a nucleus (processing happens before export). Prokaryotes have no nucleus (mRNA is used immediately).

wrong.error: You confused the 5' cap with the poly-A tail. Cap is at the 5' end; poly-A tail is at the 3' end.
wrong.fix: 5' cap = methyl group added to the 5' end (protects from degradation). Poly-A tail = adenines added to 3' end (stability).
wrong.action: Think of mRNA like a sentence: cap = capital letter at start (5'). Poly-A = period at end (3').

wrong.error: You thought splicing adds sequences. Splicing REMOVES introns and joins exons together.
wrong.fix: Splicing = cut out introns, paste exons together. Nothing is added during splicing; sequences are removed.
wrong.action: Splicing is like editing a film: remove the unwanted scenes (introns), keep the good parts (exons).

persistent.gap: You're not understanding the modifications that convert pre-mRNA to mature mRNA.
persistent.action: Draw pre-mRNA, then show: 1) cap added to 5' end, 2) poly-A added to 3' end, 3) introns spliced out.

concepts.name: genetic code
concepts.formula: The genetic code is universal (same in all organisms), triplet (3 bases per codon), and degenerate (multiple codons per amino acid)
concepts.correct: Correct! The genetic code uses triplet codons, is universal across life, and is degenerate because multiple codons can encode the same amino acid (64 codons for 20 amino acids).

wrong.error: You confused degenerate with defective. Degenerate means redundant—multiple codons code for the same amino acid.
wrong.fix: Degenerate = redundancy, not error. Having multiple codons for one amino acid provides a buffer against mutations.
wrong.action: Example: Leucine has 6 codons. Mutations in the third position often don't change the amino acid (wobble).

wrong.error: You thought there are 20 codons for 20 amino acids. There are 64 codons (4³) for 20 amino acids.
wrong.fix: 4 bases × 4 bases × 4 bases = 64 possible codons. 61 code for amino acids; 3 are stop codons. Multiple codons per amino acid.
wrong.action: Calculate: 4³ = 64 codons. 64 codons ÷ 20 amino acids = average of ~3 codons per amino acid.

wrong.error: You thought the genetic code varies between species. It's nearly universal across all life.
wrong.fix: The same codons specify the same amino acids in bacteria, plants, and animals. This universality enables genetic engineering.
wrong.action: Universality allows human insulin genes to work in bacteria—same code, same amino acid assignments.

persistent.gap: You're not understanding the properties of the genetic code.
persistent.action: List three properties: 1) Universal (same everywhere), 2) Triplet (3 bases = 1 codon), 3) Degenerate (redundant).

concepts.name: translation process
concepts.formula: Ribosomes read mRNA codons, tRNA anticodons deliver amino acids, and peptide bonds form until a stop codon is reached
concepts.correct: Correct! Translation occurs when ribosomes read mRNA codons, tRNAs with complementary anticodons bring specific amino acids, peptide bonds form between amino acids, continuing until a stop codon terminates the process.

wrong.error: You confused codons with anticodons. Codons are on mRNA; anticodons are on tRNA.
wrong.fix: Codon = triplet on mRNA (e.g., AUG). Anticodon = triplet on tRNA (e.g., UAC). They're complementary.
wrong.action: mRNA has the message (codons). tRNA translates it (anticodons match codons, bring correct amino acid).

wrong.error: You thought ribosomes carry amino acids. Ribosomes are the site; tRNA carries the amino acids.
wrong.fix: Ribosome = factory where translation happens. tRNA = delivery truck bringing amino acids. mRNA = instructions.
wrong.action: Ribosome reads mRNA and catalyses peptide bond formation. tRNA delivers the amino acids specified by each codon.

wrong.error: You confused start and stop codons. AUG is the start codon (methionine); UAA, UAG, UGA are stop codons.
wrong.fix: Start codon AUG = begins translation (also codes for methionine). Stop codons = end translation (no amino acid).
wrong.action: Memory: AUG = 'AUGust' starts the school year. Stop codons: U Are Gone, U Are Away, U Go Away.

persistent.gap: You're not understanding the roles of mRNA, tRNA, and ribosomes in translation.
persistent.action: Draw translation: mRNA with codons, ribosome reading it, tRNA bringing amino acids, growing polypeptide chain.

concepts.name: ribosome location
concepts.formula: Free ribosomes make cytosolic proteins; rough ER ribosomes make secreted and membrane proteins
concepts.correct: Correct! Free ribosomes in the cytoplasm synthesise proteins used within the cell (cytosolic). Ribosomes on rough ER synthesise proteins destined for secretion, membranes, or lysosomes.

wrong.error: You thought all proteins are made on rough ER. Only secreted and membrane proteins use the rough ER pathway.
wrong.fix: Cytosolic proteins = made on free ribosomes. Secreted/membrane proteins = made on rough ER ribosomes.
wrong.action: Does the protein stay in the cytoplasm? → Free ribosome. Does it get exported or embedded in membrane? → Rough ER.

wrong.error: You confused rough ER with smooth ER. Rough ER has ribosomes (protein synthesis); smooth ER lacks them (lipid synthesis).
wrong.fix: Rough ER = 'rough' because of attached ribosomes (makes proteins). Smooth ER = no ribosomes (makes lipids).
wrong.action: The 'rough' appearance comes from ribosomes. Smooth ER is smooth because it has no ribosomes.

wrong.error: You thought ribosomes are different on rough ER. The ribosomes are identical; only their location differs.
wrong.fix: All ribosomes start the same. Some become attached to ER based on a signal sequence in the growing polypeptide.
wrong.action: Signal sequence = 'address label' that directs the ribosome to attach to ER. No signal = stays free.

persistent.gap: You're not distinguishing between free ribosomes and ER-bound ribosomes.
persistent.action: Draw a cell showing: free ribosomes (making cytosolic proteins) and rough ER (making secreted proteins).

concepts.name: secretory pathway
concepts.formula: Proteins move from rough ER to Golgi (modification) to vesicles for secretion via exocytosis
concepts.correct: Correct! The secretory pathway moves proteins from rough ER (synthesis) → Golgi apparatus (modification and sorting) → secretory vesicles → plasma membrane (exocytosis).

wrong.error: You thought proteins go directly from ER to the cell surface. They must pass through the Golgi first.
wrong.fix: Route: Rough ER → Golgi apparatus → secretory vesicles → plasma membrane. Golgi modifies and sorts proteins.
wrong.action: Golgi is the 'post office'—it receives, modifies (adds labels), sorts, and ships proteins to correct destinations.

wrong.error: You confused exocytosis with endocytosis. Exocytosis releases contents; endocytosis takes material in.
wrong.fix: Exocytosis = vesicle fuses with membrane, releasing contents OUT. Endocytosis = membrane engulfs material IN.
wrong.action: EXO = exit (out). ENDO = enter (in). Secretion uses exocytosis.

wrong.error: You thought the Golgi only packages proteins. It also modifies them (e.g., glycosylation, phosphorylation).
wrong.fix: Golgi functions: 1) Modify proteins (add sugars/phosphates). 2) Sort proteins by destination. 3) Package into vesicles.
wrong.action: Think of Golgi as a processing plant: receives products, adds finishing touches, sorts them, ships them out.

persistent.gap: You're not understanding the sequence of organelles in the secretory pathway.
persistent.action: Trace the path: Ribosome → Rough ER → Golgi → Vesicle → Plasma membrane. Note what happens at each step.

gene-structure.title: Understanding Gene Structure
gene-structure.instructions: Learn the basic components that make up a gene.

sentences.text: A gene consists of three main regions: the {{d1}} where RNA polymerase binds, the {{d2}} that contains the information to be transcribed, and the {{d3}} that signals the end of transcription.

d1.tooltip: The region where transcription machinery binds to initiate transcription

d2.tooltip: The portion of the gene that is transcribed

d3.tooltip: The sequence that signals the end of transcription

sentences.text: In eukaryotic genes, the coding sequence contains {{d1}}, which are the expressed sequences, and {{d2}}, which are non-coding sequences that must be removed.

d1.tooltip: Sequences that remain in mature mRNA and are expressed

d2.tooltip: Intervening sequences that are spliced out

sentences.text: Unlike eukaryotes, {{d1}} typically have genes that lack introns and are therefore called {{d2}} genes because they contain uninterrupted coding sequences.

d1.tooltip: Organisms without a nucleus

d2.tooltip: Genes without introns to interrupt the coding sequence

transcription.title: The Transcription Process
transcription.instructions: Understand how DNA is transcribed into RNA.

sentences.text: Transcription begins when {{d1}} binds to the {{d2}} and causes the DNA double helix to {{d3}} and separate.

d1.tooltip: The enzyme that synthesises RNA

d2.tooltip: The binding site for transcription initiation

d3.tooltip: The separation of DNA strands for transcription

sentences.text: RNA polymerase reads the {{d1}} strand in the {{d2}} direction and synthesises RNA in the {{d3}} direction.

d1.tooltip: The strand used as a guide for RNA synthesis

d2.tooltip: The direction the template is read

d3.tooltip: The direction of nucleic acid synthesis

sentences.text: At the {{d1}}, RNA polymerase detaches from the DNA, and the newly formed {{d2}} molecule is released.

d1.tooltip: The sequence signalling the end of transcription

d2.tooltip: The product of transcription

translation.title: Translation Basics
translation.instructions: Learn how mRNA is translated into protein.

sentences.text: The genetic code is {{d1}}, meaning the same codons specify the same amino acids in virtually all organisms, which enables genetic engineering.

d1.tooltip: The same in all living organisms

sentences.text: The genetic code is also {{d1}}, meaning that multiple different {{d2}} can code for the same amino acid, since there are 64 codons but only {{d3}} amino acids.

d1.tooltip: Multiple codons can code for one amino acid

d2.tooltip: Triplets of nucleotides

d3.tooltip: The number of standard amino acids

sentences.text: During translation, {{d1}} with complementary {{d2}} bind to mRNA codons and deliver specific {{d3}} to the growing polypeptide chain.

d1.tooltip: Transfer RNA that carries amino acids

d2.tooltip: The triplet on tRNA that pairs with mRNA

secretion.title: Protein Secretion Pathway
secretion.instructions: Understand how proteins are processed and exported from cells.

sentences.text: Proteins destined for secretion are synthesised by ribosomes attached to the {{d1}}, giving it a 'rough' appearance.

d1.tooltip: The organelle with ribosomes on its surface

sentences.text: Proteins made in the rough ER are then transported to the {{d1}}, where they may be modified by processes such as {{d2}}, which adds sugar molecules.

d1.tooltip: The organelle that modifies and sorts proteins

d2.tooltip: Adding carbohydrate groups to proteins

sentences.text: Finally, proteins are packaged into {{d1}} and released from the cell through {{d2}}, where the vesicle fuses with the plasma membrane.

d1.tooltip: Small membrane-bound sacs for transport

d2.tooltip: The process of releasing contents outside the cell

gene-structure.title: Gene Architecture
gene-structure.instructions: Apply understanding of gene structure to explain gene expression patterns.

sentences.text: The central dogma describes the flow of genetic information: {{d1}} is transcribed into {{d2}}, which is translated into {{d3}}.

d1.tooltip: The original source of genetic information

d2.tooltip: The intermediate message

sentences.text: Genes on either strand of the DNA double helix can be transcribed, allowing for {{d1}} organisation of genetic information within a {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Efficient use of DNA space

d2.tooltip: The complete set of DNA in an organism

sentences.text: {{d1}} splicing allows one gene to produce multiple different mRNA variants by selectively including or excluding specific {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Variable splicing that produces different products

d2.tooltip: The coding sequences that can be variably included

transcription.title: RNA Processing
transcription.instructions: Understand the modifications made to eukaryotic mRNA.

sentences.text: Before leaving the nucleus, eukaryotic pre-mRNA undergoes processing including addition of a {{d1}} cap at the 5' end and a {{d2}} tail at the 3' end.

d1.tooltip: The type of chemical group added to the 5' cap

d2.tooltip: A chain of adenine nucleotides added to the 3' end

sentences.text: The 5' cap protects mRNA from {{d1}} by exonucleases and helps with {{d2}} export and ribosome binding during translation.

d1.tooltip: Breakdown of the mRNA molecule

d2.tooltip: Export from the nucleus to cytoplasm

sentences.text: {{d1}} is the process that removes introns and joins exons together, performed by a complex of RNA and proteins called a {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: The removal of introns and joining of exons

d2.tooltip: The molecular machine that performs splicing

translation.title: Translation Machinery
translation.instructions: Explore the detailed mechanism of protein synthesis.

sentences.text: Translation begins when a ribosome assembles on the mRNA at the {{d1}} codon ({{d2}}), which always codes for the amino acid {{d3}}.

d1.tooltip: The codon that initiates translation

d2.tooltip: The nucleotide sequence of the start codon

d3.tooltip: The amino acid encoded by the start codon

sentences.text: The ribosome catalyses the formation of {{d1}} bonds between adjacent amino acids through a {{d2}} reaction, building the polypeptide chain.

d1.tooltip: The covalent bonds between amino acids

d2.tooltip: A reaction that releases water

sentences.text: Translation ends when the ribosome reaches a {{d1}} codon (UAA, UAG, or UGA), which does not code for an amino acid but instead triggers {{d2}} of the polypeptide.

d1.tooltip: Codons that terminate translation

d2.tooltip: The polypeptide is freed from the ribosome

secretion.title: Protein Targeting and Modification
secretion.instructions: Understand how proteins are directed to specific destinations.

sentences.text: Proteins destined for secretion contain a {{d1}} sequence at their N-terminus that directs the ribosome to attach to the {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: A sequence that acts as an address label

d2.tooltip: The organelle where secretory proteins are made

sentences.text: The Golgi apparatus has a {{d1}} face (receiving from ER) and a {{d2}} face (sending out vesicles), with proteins being modified as they pass through.

d1.tooltip: The receiving side of the Golgi

d2.tooltip: The shipping side of the Golgi

sentences.text: Proteins can be secreted {{d1}} (immediately) or stored in vesicles for {{d2}} secretion, which is triggered by specific cellular signals.

d1.tooltip: Continuous, default secretion pathway

d2.tooltip: Secretion triggered by specific signals

gene-structure.title: Gene Expression Complexity
gene-structure.instructions: Synthesise understanding of how gene structure affects expression.

sentences.text: While {{d1}} transcriptase can reverse the central dogma by synthesising DNA from RNA, this occurs primarily in {{d2}} and is not a normal cellular process.

d1.tooltip: The enzyme that makes DNA from RNA

d2.tooltip: Viruses with RNA genomes that integrate into host DNA

sentences.text: Alternative splicing contributes to {{d1}} complexity because a single gene can produce multiple {{d2}} with different functions depending on which exons are included.

d1.tooltip: The complete set of proteins

d2.tooltip: Different versions of the same protein

sentences.text: The {{d1}} is a molecular machine containing small nuclear {{d2}} and proteins that recognises splice sites and catalyses the {{d3}} of introns.

d1.tooltip: The complex that performs splicing

d2.tooltip: snRNAs that are part of the spliceosome

transcription.title: Transcriptional Control
transcription.instructions: Analyse how transcription is regulated and its relationship to processing.

sentences.text: Multiple RNA polymerase enzymes can transcribe the same gene {{d1}}, forming structures called transcription {{d2}} visible under electron microscopy.

d1.tooltip: One after another on the same template

d2.tooltip: The unwound regions where transcription occurs

sentences.text: In prokaryotes, transcription and translation can occur {{d1}} because there is no {{d2}} separating the DNA from ribosomes.

d1.tooltip: At the same time

d2.tooltip: The barrier that separates transcription from translation in eukaryotes

sentences.text: The {{d1}} strand of DNA has the same sequence as the mRNA (except T instead of {{d2}}), while the {{d3}} strand is actually read during transcription.

d1.tooltip: The strand with the same sequence as mRNA

d2.tooltip: The base in RNA that replaces thymine

translation.title: Translation Efficiency
translation.instructions: Evaluate factors affecting protein synthesis rates and accuracy.

sentences.text: Multiple ribosomes can translate the same mRNA molecule simultaneously, forming structures called {{d1}}, which increases the {{d2}} of protein production.

d1.tooltip: Groups of ribosomes on one mRNA

d2.tooltip: More protein made from each mRNA

d2.tooltip: Mutations that don't change the amino acid

secretion.title: Integrated Protein Processing
secretion.instructions: Connect the secretory pathway to cellular function and disease.

sentences.text: The rough ER has quality control mechanisms that retain {{d1}} proteins and target them for degradation via a process called ER-associated {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Proteins that haven't achieved correct structure

d2.tooltip: ERAD - removing faulty proteins
